narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Continuation of learning quantum mechanics from the first part. Scattering, Spin, etc. Very interesting stuff, and 440 was paid off by taking 441
A lot of important results in quantum theory. Angular momentum and spin, perturbation theory, a brief study of approximate methods, scattering theory, and an introduction to the Dirac equation.

In this class, I learned about the structure of the hydrogen atom; kinematics and dynamics of spin; addition of angular momentum; approximation methods like the variational method, WKB method, and perturbation theory; scattering theory; and an introduction to relativistic quantum mechanics. The two-semester sequence gave me a thorough introduction to quantum mechanics as well as a good working knowledge of procedurally solving quantum mechanical problems.
Second part of the undergrad quantum sequence. Hydrogen atom, angular momentum, perturbation theory, scattering, and the Dirac equation. Working with vector spaces and Dirac notation.
Deeper understanding of quantum mechanics, with additional topics like angular momentum, spin, perturbations, scattering, and dirac equations.

As the second semester of quantum mechanics, it built on the knowledge of the first semester and finished giving an overlying foundation in the world of quantum mechanics. In addition to the physics that we learned, it helped sharpen my mathematics and quantitative skills holistically.
I learned quantum mechanics, specifically spin, approximation methods, and perturbation theory, and I think I learned the topics much better this semester than the last due to the class structure.
I can solve actual quantum problems now. It's great.
It's the second semester of the undergraduate Quantum Physics courses. The course covered topics including angular momentum, spin, approximation methods, perturbation theory and scattering.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Shankar is an excellent instructor, and there is something unique about his style of teaching that has just "worked for me" very well. As someone who made a habit of attending class, I think doing so was extremely beneficial to my understanding. The topics I struggled with the most were angular momentum (juggling dozens of properties of Jz, Lz, Sz, J^2, L^2, S^2 frequently got my wires crossed) and scattering theory (motivation for certain expressions, such as a differential cross section or a phase shift), both of which I was able to get some simpler intuition on from Griffith's textbook. I prefer Prof. Shankar's textbook at large (particularly his approach to introducing quantum theory), but I think other sources give more straightforward intuition in later chapters.

Strengths: Professor Shankar is a skilled lecturer and has useful analogies in quantum mechanics. The problem sets were challenging and were very good practice. Weaknesses: The book contains too much information for it to be useful as a textbook; it is better as a reference. Sometimes Professor Shankars pacing is a bit strange. Hell often blow right through calculations that could use some more time, and sometimes hell belabor a point that doesnt seem to require as much emphasis.

Strength: Professor Shankar did his best to be available and he clearly put a lot of work into the course from lectures, prerecorded lectures, learning goals, etc. Weakness: The problem sets weren't too representative on the exams and were also a bit erratic (i.e. one week there would be a 12 week problem set and the next week would only have 3 questions)
It has executed very well given the circumstances, and I really enjoyed the course.

The strengths of this course include the accessibility of the pre-recorded lectures and the learning goals for each lecture tailored to ensure students understood the core concepts. The main weakness of this course was the lack of timeliness in which problem sets were returned.
This course was solid, I don't have any weaknesses for it. The set-up was a strength, as was the quality of the lectures and meetings.

The flipped classroom format is very effective and conducive for learning. The lectures were pre-recorded and came with quizzes and we were required to watch them before class. During the class meeting times, Prof. Shankar went over learning goals he prepared for us and practice problems with us and answered questions. Although the course was conducted remotely, Prof. Shankar has put in a lot of efforts into helping us understand the concept and improving our problem-solving skills.

One weakness was that it took a long time for us to receive some of the pset grades. This happened more often during the second half of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The double lecture format inadvertently doubled the amount of work for the students.
There was a pre-recorded lecture to watch before hand, and then important takeaways during class. I think initially the class time was meant for questions and a problem session, but why have a lecture before hand, only to say "this is what's really important" in class? why not just start with what's important, instead of double-teaching things with extra stuff that's not important.
I appreciated the flipped classroom, and I think it made me more successful than I was in the prior semester.

I found the flipped classroom style helpful for quantum mechanics, since I got exposed to the material twice, and I got to practice it twice (in class and on problem sets). I also got to slow down or speed up the lectures as necessary. The problem-solving in class made for high engagement.
The combined lecture/section format worked extremely well, I thought. I felt like I had a grasp of the material at every step of the way, and didn't struggle to keep up.

Shankar's availability and dedication to this course really shined through and helped this course to be a success. I cannot think of anything Shankar could've done to improve the course based on the course structure.
I think this course handled the challenges brought by Covid very well.

The successful practices include the recorded lectures and learning goal discussions; however, attendance was not mandatory, and this led to many students not showing up. Virtual engagement can be improved by shortening the time needed to view lectures, as watching the pre-recorded lectures and attending the synchronous learning goal discussions effectively doubled the class time.
The system Prof Shankar set up for this course worked. I learned very well with the prerecorded lectures in combination with the in class review. I felt that this really reinforced the material.
The recorded lecture + discussion session format worked very well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you've taken 440. I presume if it were in-person it would be far better.

I would recommend this course and PHYS 440 to anyone wanting an introduction to quantum mechanics. Though I am not sure what the B.S. sequence is like, I found this more advanced sequence highly rewarding.
Yes! The 440-441 sequence is a complete introduction to quantum physics and is essential for any aspiring physicist.
Yes, absolutely. One of the best classes in the Intensive Physics track. Prof. Shankar's lectures are clear, understandable, and engaging.

If you're a physics intensive student, you have no choice. If you want to get a deeper understanding of quantum mechanics, yes. However, even as a physics intensive major, I don't see myself using this subject much, if at all, in the future.
Definitely, not only is it such a vital class in your physics career. Its one of the classes that makes you, understand and appreciate the world to another level.

I would recommend this course to another student for how well it is facilitated for online physics learning during a pandemic. However, every intensive physics major is required to take this course anyway.
You can only take this if you've already taken 440, so you're probably already going to take this. That being said, I found this class to be a lot more interesting and enjoyable than 440.
This is the best class that I have taken so far at Yale. If Professor Shankar is still teaching QM, definitely take it with him. He makes things absolutely clear and truly cares about students.
